articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website
articles.contents:
About Me
I am Elif Kuyuk, a current junior at Bartlett High School. Among many
various hobbies, I enjoy hiking and gardening. Learning new things is
always a pleasure, especially if accompanied with friends.
Contact Information
Email: ekuyuk04@gmail.com
Github: https://github.com/ekuyuk
About the Project
This project briefly observes and analyzes what might be affecting a
students performance. Family life, genetics, environmental cues; these
all play a big role in a students success. Finding out the main factors,
and potentially inspiring us students to beneficially work with such
factors, is the main goal.
Goals
Comparing genetic factors (race, gender)
Analyzing individual factors (study session before test, lunch
type)
Finding out the main factor affecting a students behavior from the
factors included in the data set.
Obstacles: Expected
Organizing the data, finding out the best way to correctly visualize
the patterns.
Column/row management and graphing
““This is Data Science””
~ Preceptor

articles.title: Student Performance
articles.description:
The success of a student relies on many different factors; knowing how to 
handle and control these factors will increase a students performance.
articles.contents:
A students success and beneficial academic performance depends on
various factors. The following data was pulled from Kaggle. Graphs were
used to represent the correlation between test scores and parental level
of education, lunch type, race, test preparation, and gender. Students
that were not taking a free/reduced lunch, had taken the preparation
course, and had parents with an education level above high school were
observed to have higher scores.

articles.title: Effects of Lunch on Student Performance
articles.contents:
After Viewing the relationship between parental levels of education,
gender, and ethnicity, one wonders how these all tie in with the factor
of nutrition, lunch.
Below is the plot depicting how many students in this data were
of each category, and of those, how many received either standard or
free/reduced lunch.



With all levels of education having about the same ratios, it awakens
interest to find out if a difference in lunch in each level is causing
high/low scores.
Below is one visual illustrating the correlation between the four
factors: lunch, parental level of education, and gender.
It is clear that “high school” and “some high school” are most
heavily affected by lunch type. In terms of gender distribution, in most
parental levels of education and lunch types, female students have a
lower average.



The following plots compare the statistics for each gender,
by test type and lunch type.
Plot 1



Plot 2
Plot 3

articles.title: page
articles.contents:
Overview Of Reading Scores
As seen below, ethnic Group D has a tighter range, and denser test
scores. Female students have scores higher than the male students for
this group; students with a parent holding a masters degree has the
smallest range, and an average higher than other levels of education –
this same pattern of parental level of education can be spotted in group
C as well. Ethnic groups A, E, and B, can be seen having less students
with a parent holding a masters degree, and looser clusters.


student<- read.csv("StudentsPerformance.csv")
student|> 
select(parental.level.of.education, math.score, writing.score, reading.score, gender, race.ethnicity)|> 
ggplot(mapping = aes(y = parental.level.of.education, x = reading.score, color = gender))+
  geom_point(alpha = 0.3, size = 5) + 
  facet_wrap(~race.ethnicity)+ 
  theme_calc()+
  labs(title = "Reading Scores", subtitle = "Cluster of higher scores can be observed for all race groups with a parental 
level of education = Associates Degree", x = "Reading Scores", y = "Parental Level of Education", caption = "Kaggle: JAKKI SESHAPANPU 2018")



Overview of Math Scores
Compared to reading scores, all groups of scores have higher
averages. Male students seem to be dominating higher scores in most
groups, and score distrubiton seems to be equal in a few groups (such as
group E and A).


student<- read.csv("StudentsPerformance.csv")
# Starting data analysis
student|> 
select(parental.level.of.education, math.score, writing.score, reading.score, gender, race.ethnicity)|>
# Command "select()" allows for only the wanted columns to be viewed  
ggplot(mapping = aes(y = parental.level.of.education, x = math.score, color = gender))+
  geom_point(alpha = 0.3, size = 5) + 
  facet_wrap(~race.ethnicity)+ 
  theme_calc()+
  labs(title = "Math Scores", subtitle = "Male students have higher scores.", x = "Math Scores", y = "Parental Level of Education", caption = "Kaggle: JAKKI SESHAPANPU 2018")



Overview of Writing Scores
Strongly contrasting the gender distribution for math scores, the
higher scores for writing are dominated by female students. This pattern
can be observed in every ethnic group, without pause. Similar to the
other scores, students with a parent holding a masters degree have a
higher score average, and smaller range for all groups except A. Group B
and C have the lowest average writing score when parental level of
education is “high school”

articles.title: Sources
articles.contents:
Data:
Data “Students Performances in Exams” was originally composed by
JAKKI SESHAPANPU, which was last updated 4 years ago.
Link: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/spscientist/students-performance-in-exams?resource=download
